pros: Typically we have numerous projects on the go, with support from colleagues and an understanding from hospital peers about how we can help fundraise for their priorities. There are a lot of opportunities for writers to engage with and interview patients, families and scientists or other staff at the hospital while writing reports, articles and podcast episodes.
cons: This fast-paced environment, where the workload can be intense during parts of the year, won't suit everyone.

pros: professional growth is highly encouragede
cons: highly competitive roles within the public sector

pros: Good for stability The mission is understandable
cons: Growth can be limited Pay is fine for the sector

pros:

pros: Unique opportunity to work at the intersection of fundraising and public engagement with an innovative approach
cons: Balancing the marketing guidelines of the hospital and foundation can be challenging without adequate direction and preparation

pros: Sickkids has cut edge equipment and facilities and provide good benefits
cons: sometimes the atmosphere gets too competitive

pros: Sickkids Foundation allow employees to have flexible working hours

pros: Friendly environment, supportive staff, clean

pros: interesting work and complex problems to solve.
cons:
toxic workplace culture. 
conflict adverse and conservative upper management allow abusive behaviour to go unchecked for far too long
shiny brand and exterior perception is at odds with internal workings

pros: Great place to work, with amazing people
cons: No cons to share at all

pros:
- Knowledgeable Fundraising team
- Great enthusiasm in direct marketing, events and finance teams
- Monthly dept themed snack parties
- Good Summer hours.
- Dedicated staff, overall.
cons:
- Foundation tends to waste a lot of donor money on agencies and outsourcing of work.
- Recurring favoritism in IT dept with strong sense of favouritism and micromanagement.
- Project Managers in I.T act indifferent, lack courtesy and suffer from mood swings.
- Lack of integrity and technical experience in Client Service Managers. 
- HR dept usually plays by rules of favouritism.

pros: Great Benefits, 80:20 Female/Male Ratio, Great Cause
cons: Senior Management allows for very little autonomy. They think by monitoring your every move that this will increase productivity. There is also a huge disconnect between SM and the rest of the team members. Huge overhaul needs to be done in order to allow people the room to properly develop into their roles, and actually breathe!! They also do not care about your performance. They care mostly about the numbers. A few employees during my time there were let go at the end of their probation period with no explanation and one hour to pack up their things and leave.

pros:
Good salary, vacation time and benefits with a matching pension scheme.
The Foundation raises money for such a good cause, where the work conducted at the hospital is simply amazing and the staff are dedicated to the work they do.
cons: Where to begin - the environment is toxic and unfriendly, lots of red tape so trying to get any projects done is like pulling teeth, senior management lack any positive energy or motivational spirit (they only complain), high turn over from new staff (staff can fired for no reason or because of personal grudges), very unfriendly and miserable place to work, materialistic and Instagram obsessed culture

review_title: Good cause, poor management and leadership that doesn't value people.
pros: Great cause, lots of opportunity to connect with hospital, donors and patients. Staff at lower management and non-management level are great for the most part- all there for similar reasons.
cons: Leadership team and President very command and control- not interested in innovation, developing people or providing autonomy.

pros: Offered me competitive pay and benefits, plus a  professional development budget. They spend money on every fundraising idea imaginable, so there a huge opportunity to see learn.
cons: It's incredibly competitive. Managers play favourites. You need thick skin, expensive clothing and the ability to manage up.

review_title: IT/BI/Developer review: disappointing experience, read reviews carefully

pros:
exposure in not for Profit segment
3weeks vacation
cons:
- do NOT take the job if you're on top of your game

- I heard they finally got rid of some bad managers, but still issues remain. They have serious culture problems which wont be solved by firing one or two managers
- revolving door, zero stability,zero room to grow skills

review_title: Incredible cause, creative and well-rounded team
pros:
- The cause is of course inspiring, validating, and motivating
- The work is interesting and engaging, interesting challenges that require creative and strategic solutions
- Intelligent coworkers
cons:
- Long winded project processes, but that's to be expected from a 100+ person company
- Growth takes years to achieve

pros: A great working environment that fosters growth and collaboration. I'm particularly lucky that my supervisor was a generous mentor in all aspects. I couldn't imagine doing my graduate work anywhere else.
cons: Unfortunately, the benefits at Sick Kids are minimal compared to other research facilities. Especially for post-doctoral students.

pros:

pros: Great team, wonderful location. renowned hospital
